questions.question: Question 1: How is the normal placenta described?
questions.explanation:
74 
Sold by @itachibot The normal human placenta is discoid, deciduate, and hemochorial. The term deciduate means that the placenta is shed at the time of parturition. Hemochorial 
means that the maternal blood directly comes in contact with the fetal trophoblasts. The image given below shows a normal human placenta.

questions.question: Question 2: What does a placental cotyledon comprise of?

options.a: Portions of the basal plate divided by clefts
options.b: Portions of the chorionic plate divided by cleft
options.c: Area supplied by multiple truncal chorionic villi
options.d: Area supplied by one spiral artery

questions.explanation:
A placental cotyledon is comprised of portions of the basal plate divided by clefts. It is the 
functional unit of the placenta. A placental cotyledon or placental lobule constitutes one truncal or main stem villi and its 
ramifications (rami). Each lobule is supplied by a single truncal branch of the chorionic artery. 
Each lobule also has a single vein. The lobules constitute functional units of placental 
architecture. The fetal surface is the chorionic plate. The umbilical cord inserts in the center of the chorionic 
plate. Note: The entire placenta is supplied by chorionic villi while each cotyledon is only supplied by a 
single main stem villus with its branches. 75 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following does not contribute to the prevention of rejection of fetus?
questions.explanation:
Maternal leucopenia is not seen in pregnancy, instead leucocytosis is seen. This plays no part in 
the prevention of rejection of fetus. The fetus is a semiallogenic graft inside the maternal body as half of its genes are from the father. 
Uterine transplantation immunity contributes to the survival of the fetus in spite of it being 
semiallogenic. This occurs due to the following factors: • Decidual natural killer cells are inefficient, and therefore are unable to attack the 'foreign' fetal 
cells. • Decidual stromal cells work with natural killer cells to allow trophoblastic invasion. • Villous trophoblastic cells don't express HLA antigens and therefore, they are non-immunogenic. 76 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: At what period of gestation are the weights of the fetus and placenta equal?
questions.explanation:
At 17 weeks, the weights of the fetus and placenta are equal. In the first trimester, the placental growth is more rapid than that of the fetus. By approximately 
17 weeks, the placental weight and fetal weight are almost equal. And by term, placental weight is 
approximately 1/6th of the fetal weight.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.explanation: The uteroplacental blood flow at term is 500-750 ml/min.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is false about human chorionic gonadotropin?

options.a: Alpha subunit is identical to LH, FSH, TSH
options.b: It causes involution of corpus luteum
options.c: Maximum level is seen at 60-70 days of gestation
options.d: Detected in serum 8-9 days after fertilisation

questions.explanation:
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) does not cause involution of the corpus luteum, but it 
maintains corpus luteum function. hCG is produced by the syncitiotrophoblasts of the placenta. It is a glycoprotein hormone with 
two subunits. The alpha-subunit is similar to LH, FSH and TSH. The beta-subunit is specific and 
is measured by pregnancy tests. hCG can be detected in maternal blood 8 days after fertilisation. Thus, it can help in diagnosis of 
pregnancy even before the period is missed. Its levels nearly doubles every 48 hours in early 
pregnancy reaching a maximum of 50000 - 100000 IU/L by 60-70 days of gestation. Then the 
level starts falling reaching a minimum at 16 weeks, which continues throughout pregnancy. The various placental hormones and their functions are given below. Other placental hormones include: • GnRH, TRH, GHRH, Growth hormone variant (hGH-V) • Parathyroid hormone-releasing protein (PTH-rP) • Inhibin • Activin • Relaxin Placental hormones 
Functions Human chorionic gonadotrop 
in (hCG)Structurally similar t

ctionRegulates testosterone s

ulates maternal thyroid 77 
Sold by @itachibot Placental hormones

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following cannot cross the placenta?
questions.explanation:
Albumin and IgM cannot cross the placenta. High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the 
placenta, except IgG. Substances which can cross the placenta are as follows: Note: Maternal hormones like insulin, steroid hormones, and thyroid hormones cross the placenta 
very slowly, and only in amounts enough to support fetal development. However, calcitonin and 
parathormone do not cross the placenta. Substances 
Mechanism O2CO2WaterElectrolytesAne 
sthetic agents Simple diffusion Endocytosis via Fc receptors 
in the trophoblast Immunoglobulin G(molecula

questions.question:
Question 8: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal 
delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition 
known as? 67 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
78 
Sold by @itachibot The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened 
and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial 
placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of 
extrachorial placentation: • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal 
plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed 
of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are: • Preterm delivery • Abortions • IUGR • Antepartum hemorrhage • Retained placenta and membranes 79 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying 
distances from the main placental margins. Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present 
between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.question:
Question 9: Following a normal vaginal delivery, the placenta delivered by controlled cord traction 
appeared as shown below. What is this condition known as?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a placenta with a small, accessory lobe. This condition is known 
as placenta succenturiata. A succenturiate placenta contains single or multiple accessory lobes. Accessory lobes are attached 
to the main lobe by a membrane that has a leash of blood vessels. Option A: Bilobate placenta - it consists of two placental lobes. The cord inserts between the two 
lobes. Option C: Placenta membranacea - entire surface of the fetal membranes are covered by 
functioning villi and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure occupying the entire 
periphery of the chorion. Option D: Placenta marginata - chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and a thin margin 
is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.question:
Question 10: The USG scan of a multiparous woman at 30 weeks of gestation showed the presence of an 
accessory placental lobe. Which complication will you not anticipate in her?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of the presence of an accessory placental lobe is suggestive of placenta 
succenturiata. Preterm delivery is not a complication seen in this condition. Complications of placenta succenturiata include: • Retained placenta 80 
Sold by @itachibot • Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) • Subinvolution of uterus • Sepsis • Placental polyp formation • Vasa previa - vessels overlying the accessory lobes can cross the cervix. Their rupture can lead to 
hemorrhage from the fetus Note: Preterm delivery is a complication associated with circumvallate placenta.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows placenta increta. Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and 
imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types: • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium. • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium. • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be: • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via 
C-section and peripartum hysterectomy. 81 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: What contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma contributes to the formation of amniotic fluid during early 
pregnancy. Amniotic fluid is formed by: • Early pregnancy - ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma. • Second trimester - the extracellular fluid that diffuses through the fetal skin and thus reflects the 
composition of fetal plasma. • After 20 weeks - keratinization of fetal skin prevents diffusion across the skin. Hence, fetal urine 
forms amniotic fluid. Note: Fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks (8–11 weeks), and by 18 weeks, they produce 
7 to 14 mL per day.

questions.question:
Question 13: While performing the USG assessment of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you note her 
amniotic fluid index to be 12.8. When does this parameter reach its maximum value in a 
normal pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is a measure of the amniotic volume which is maximum at 34 
weeks of gestation. The volume of amniotic fluid at each week is variable. The volume gradually increases till 32-34 
weeks of gestation. At 34 weeks, it is maximum and thereafter there is a gradual reduction till 
term. Amniotic fluid volume is a passive reflector of the fetal condition. Its volume is determined by the 
following: Any alteration in fetal homeostasis, caused by fetal and maternal conditions, affects the amniotic 
fluid volume. Thus, AFI is measured as a part of the biophysical score. Pathway 
Volume in ml Fetal urination 
+1000 Fetal swallowing 
-750 Fetal lung fluid secretion 
+350 -350 Intramembranous flow acros 
s fetal vessels on the placenta 
l surface

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a function of amniotic fluid?

options.c: Provide nutrition in the form of fat and protein
options.d: Prevent ascending infection to uterine cavity during labor

questions.explanation:
The nutritive value of amniotic fluid is negligible because amniotic fluid is predominantly water. It 
contains the following: • Water - 98–99% 82 
Sold by @itachibot • Solids 1–2% - Organic, inorganic, suspended particles Functions of amniotic fluid during pregnancy: • It acts as a shock absorber and prevents trauma to the fetus • Temperature regulation of the uterine environment • It distends the amniotic sac and thereby allows for growth and free movement of the fetus. • It has no nutritive function, as it is mostly formed by water. • Bacteriostatic property Functions of amniotic fluid during labor: • The amnion and chorion are combined to form a hydrostatic wedge which helps in dilatation of 
the cervix. • During uterine contraction, it prevents any interference in placental circulation so long as the 
membranes remain intact. • It protects the umbilical cord by providing a cushion between the fetus and the umbilical cord 
during contraction • It flushes the birth canal at the end of the first stage of labor and by its aseptic action protects 
the fetus and prevents ascending infection to the uterine cavity.

questions.question: Question 15: When does keratinization of fetal skin occur?
questions.explanation:
Keratinization of fetal skin occurs at 22–25 weeks. Therefore, diffusion across fetal skin does not 
occur after this period. So fetal plasma does not contribute to amniotic fluid formation after this 
time period.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following statements is false about amniotic fluid?

options.b: Major source is fetal urine after 20 weeks
options.c: It is primarily reabsorbed by fetal swallowing

questions.explanation:
The composition of amniotic fluid is not the same throughout pregnancy but changes later in 
pregnancy due to contamination by fetal urinary metabolites. In early pregnancy, it is identical to plasma in composition as it is mainly composed of a 
transudate of plasma. In late pregnancy, as amniotic fluid is primarily formed by fetal urination, 
the composition is altered. Disorders of the fetal kidney can lead to oligohydramnios. Fetal swallowing is the primary method of resorption of amniotic fluid. Disorders of swallowing in 
the fetus can cause polyhydramnios. Amniotic fluid is alkaline in nature and this helps in differentiating it from vaginal secretions 
which are acidic. This forms the basis of the nitrazine paper test used for the diagnosis 
of premature rupture of membranes. 83 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A multigravida presents at 34 weeks of gestation with preterm premature rupture of 
membranes. On examination, the amniotic fluid is golden-colored. Which condition will you 
suspect here?
questions.explanation:
Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to presence of 
excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to hemolysis of fetal RBCs. Color of amniotic fluid 
Conditions Pale straw 
Near-term due to exfoliated l 
anugo hairs, exfoliated cells f 
rom fetal skin Green 
MeconiumListeria infection Golden-yellow 
Rh-incompatibility Saffron 
Post-maturity Blood-stained

a Dark maroon

emorrhage Brown (Tobacco juice) 
Intrauterine fetal demise

questions.question:
Question 18: Ultrasound findings of a few patients are given below. Which of the following patients have 
oligohydramnios?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, an AFI of 4.5cm (<5cm) or an SDP of 1.8cm (<2cm) indicate 
oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios means an abnormally decreased amount of amniotic fluid (liquor volume is 
<200ml). It is diagnosed using ultrasound parameters such as: • Single deepest pocket (SDP) - The largest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid identified in the 
sagittal plane on ultrasound is the SDP. The normal range of SDP is between 2 to 
8cm. Oligohydramnios is diagnosed if SDP < 2cm. • Amniotic fluid index (AFI) - It is the sum of the deepest pocket of amniotic fluid from each 
quadrant of the abdomen. The normal range of AFI is between 5 to 25 cm. Oligohydramnios is 
diagnosed if AFI < 5cm.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 24-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. On 
examination, size of the uterus corresponds to 26 weeks of gestation and the fetal heart rate is 
130 beats/min. On ultrasound, AFI is 4. Which fetal anomaly would you suspect?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of oligohydramnios. It is associated with renal agenesis. Oligohydramnios has the following features: • Fundal height less than period of gestation • Fetal parts easily palpable • AFI <5cm • SDP <2cm 84 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A 30-year-old G3P2L2 woman with multifetal pregnancy is diagnosed with polyhydramnios. 
What is the amniotic fluid volume required to diagnose it as this condition?
questions.explanation:
Polyhydramnios is an abnormal increase in amniotic fluid. It is defined as the presence of 
amniotic fluid volume >2000ml. Ultrasound parameters used to diagnose polyhydramnios are: • AFI > 25 cm • SDP > 8 cm

questions.question:
Question 21: A lady at 30 weeks of gestation came for an antenatal check-up. On examination, the uterus 
corresponds to 34 weeks of gestation and FHR is normal. Ultrasound revealed an AFI of 26 
cm. Which fetal anomaly is most likely to be seen with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of polyhydramnios. It can be seen with a fetus having 
a cleft palate as fetal swallowing is impaired by this anomaly. Polyhydramnios has the following features: • Fundal height greater than period of gestation • Fetal parts are not well palpable • AFI >25cm • SDP >8cm

questions.question:
Question 22: A routine ultrasound of a multigravida at 28 weeks of gestation revealed an AFI of 27cm. 
Which of the following cannot cause the given condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of polyhydramnios. Preeclampsia is a cause for 
oligohydramnios, and not polyhydramnios.

questions.question:
Question 23: 72 
Sold by @itachibot A 28-year-old G2P1L1 at 35 weeks of gestation is complaining of difficulty in breathing. On 
examination, flanks are full, and abdominal girth is 160cm. Ultrasound determined that the 
SDP is 10cm. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of polyhydramnios associated with respiratory distress. In 
such cases, therapeutic amniocentesis termed amnioreduction is done. Amnioreduction helps in polyhydramnios by: • Relieving respiratory distress by reducing mechanical pressure on the diaphragm • May improve obstructive uropathy • May lower the preterm delivery risk if the patient has preterm labor or premature rupture of 
membranes Option A: Diuretics have no role in this condition. Option B: Indomethacin therapy used to be given earlier as it reduced amnionic fluid volume. 
However, it is not given anymore due to the risk of premature closure of ductus arteriosus. 85 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is avoided as: • It cannot be employed in a patient with an unfavourable cervix. • Once ARM is done, delivery needs to be performed. In this case, preterm delivery would occur, 
hence ARM is avoided. • ARM should be used with caution in patients with chronic polyhydramnios. It can lead to 
sudden decompression of the uterus causing placental abruption. Thus, controlled ARM is done in 
these patients.

questions.question:
Question 24: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic 
blood flow. What is the management?

options.b: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
options.c: Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is 
immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can 
be terminated by cesarean section. Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery: • Reduced end-diastolic flow indicates uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases) • Absent end-diastolic flow suggests fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by 
C-section if >34 weeks. • Reverse end-diastolic flow suggests impending doom of death, hence the pregnancy is 
terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord?

options.a: It has one artery and two veins
options.b: It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
options.c: Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
options.d: Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cms

questions.explanation:
The umbilical cord normally has two arteries and one vein. The presence of a single umbilical 
artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the cord. It is associated with congenital 
anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies. 86 
Sold by @itachibot The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the fetus to the placenta. It contains umbilical vessels 
and an obliterated allantois duct, all surrounded by Wharton's jelly and contained within an outer 
layer of amnion. Maternal blood enters the fetus through the umbilical vein, and blood exits the 
fetus via the two umbilical arteries. Wharton's jelly is a gelatinous mucopolysaccharide that 
protects the umbilical vessels. Local collections of Wharton's jelly produce false knots in the cord. The average length of the umbilical cord is between 40-70 cm at term. A long cord can form a loop 
around the fetus' neck and can cause asphyxia. A short cord can result in cord rupture during 
labor.

questions.question:
Question 26: Ultrasound of a 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation shows the presence of a 
single umbilical artery. No other gross fetal anomalies were detected. Which of the following 
is true regarding this finding?
questions.explanation:
A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It 
indicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus. A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions: • Twin pregnancy • Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes • Epilepsy • Oligohydramnios • Polyhydramnios • Preeclampsia • Antepartum hemorrhage It is frequently associated with congenital malformations of the fetus (20–25%) such as: • Cardiovascular anomalies • Genitourinary anomalies • Trisomy 18 It increases the risks of adverse obstetric outcomes like: • Abortion • Fetal aneuploidy • Prematurity • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) • Perinatal mortality 87 
Sold by @itachibot Sexual Development, Puberty and Adolescence
